Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced agency. Due to the

 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.

 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.

If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

ALLEGATION:
Youth A was dismissed from the agency on 7/14/21 after going AWOL. On
9/2/21, Youth A had his own medications as well as another youth’s
medications from the agency. The agency was informed about the
medication. The agency informed the Reporting Source to dispose of the
additional medication.
INVESTIGATION:
 This investigation was initiated on 9/17/21. Both Youth A and Youth B went
AWOL from the program. Youth A was discharged from the agency on
7/2/2021. Youth B was discharged from the agency on 6/26/2021.
 Youth A nor Youth B were interviewed for this investigation.
I interviewed the Reporting Source regarding this allegation. She reported that
Youth A informed his foster parent on 9/2/21 that he had another youth medication
from Methodist Children Home. She said the foster parent provided Youth B’s
medication to her. She said she learned of this incident recently. The Reporting
Source said she called the agency and reported the medication mishap. She said
she was informed by the agency representative to dispose of the medication
because both youths were discharged from the agency. The Reporting Source
reported the medications were Ibuprofen 600mg and Methocarbamol 500mg. She
said the
Methocarbamol 500mg is for muscle spasms. She did not have any additional
information to add.
I interviewed the agency Director of Child Welfare Programs. She reported
Youth A was placed in the independent living program on 3/19/21 and went AWOL
from 5/22-5/25, 6/10-6/19, and lastly on 7/14. She said the agency had submitted a
30-day notice to send Youth As case back to DHHS after his second AWOL on
6/10/21.
She said Youth A’s DHHs caseworker emailed the agency foster care supervisor on
7/21/21 after his 3rd AWOL, indicating that she had a colleague that would be in the
area on 7/22/21 for a training, and was hoping she could pick up Youth As
3

medication and belongings. She said the agency foster care supervisor indicated
that this would not be a problem and notified the ILP cottage supervisor indicating
that this would be occurring. On 7/22/21 a DHHS employee came to pick up the
medication from the cottage. The cottage supervisor provided the medications to the
DHHS employee. The medications were in a plastic bag, which included Youth A’s
savings.
The Director of Child Welfare Program said on 09/17/2021 the agency foster care
supervisor received an email from DHHS indicating that another youth's medication
was provided to DHHS in error. She said the youth is no longer in the program, and
the only medication that he had been prescribed was an over-the-counter
prescription for Motrin, that he was taking for an ankle injury, but was no longer
taking due to no longer being in the program. The worker said she believe that
Youth A’s medication was stuck to Youth B’s and the medication was grabbed in
error.
The Director did not discuss the agency policy on handling of medication when a
youth is no longer in the program.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12503 Policy and procedures
(2) The policies and procedures shall cover at least all of
the following areas:
(h) Medical, dental, and mental health care.
ANALYSIS: It is a fact that Youth A had Youth B’s medication in his
possession and reported it to his foster parent who gave it to
Youth A’s caseworker. It is a fact that Youth A and Youth B
were not in the agency and neither were taking the medication.
The agency Director of Child Welfare Programs said she believe
that Youth A’s medication was stuck to Youth B’s and the
medication was grabbed in error. Based on the information
provided, the agency is found in violation with this rule.
Handling of medications of any kind needs to be handled with
caution and within the agency policy and procedures outline for
medications. The agency is asked to develop a plan for
disposing of medication and/or assuring that medication is
provided to the correct youth upon discharge.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
